So I have always love astronomy, space exploration, NASA, and science in general. Having a bachelors in molecular biology i can nerd out pretty easily over the smallest things. My main hobby asside from biology and healthcare is astronomy. KSP filled every nitch of space nerdism i need especially with the great modding community out there im having a blast learning it.

What i want to know for you out there that understand the math and physics of the KSP flight (and i know you are out there i read forums where math equations get brought out pretty rapidly), what are some good books/sites on the physics of spacecraft and setting up orbits ect. I think you guys know what i am talking about. I want to be able to calculate where i am going and whats going on other than just taking guesses all the time. This post may or may not make it but see what you guys give me. Thanks

For traditional(ish) texbooks, Fundamentals of Astrodynamics is pretty well recommended.

There are also some resources on orbital parameters here and here.
nice thank you exactly what i was wanting! ;D

This also a common textbook

http://www.amazon.com/Introduction-Modern-Astrophysics-2nd-Edition/dp/0805304029

Lots of places call it BOB or the big orange book. isn\'t cheap though
